5503: Goblin token card.author: Mode
5503: Goblin token card.text_parsed:
I'm wondering why only the Unglued token is included here.

Maybe either because it shows nothing but a picture while the others are visibly 1/1 Goblin creatures, or (which i suspect to be more likely) because it's the only card that could be found in a booster with the original card back, while the others aren't considered actual magic cards for having a special expansion set image on the back instead?
Although this is true for the Shards of Alara and Tenth Edition one, i don't exctly know what's on the back of those from Elves vs. Goblins (although the art is identifac to the Tenth Edition one), and especially not that from the 2003 Player Rewards (which has the Legions expansion symbol).

Possibly this means the Unglued ones will stay the only tokens to be found in Gatherer, although i'd love to see the others as well.

5503: Goblin token card.author: Aaron_Forsythe
5503: Goblin token card.text_parsed:
Aaron’s Random Card Comment of the Day #61, 2/8/11

The Unglued set is oft-maligned, but even if you aren’t the kind of player that uses goofy silvered-bordered cards you should appreciate the number of “real” designs that have grown out the experimentation of the Un- sets. They’re like Mark Rosewater’s personal proving ground, somewhere he can try things outside of the box that existing rules or product specs can’t handle to see if players like them, at which point the necessary steps can be taken to make them “real.”

These tokens are one of the best examples of said experiments. At that point, card-sized tokens hadn’t been included in any product, so Mark commissioned a handful of full-frame art for just that purpose. His layout has not text on it whatsoever, leaving their use open-ended. Later iterations of the printed token, including the ones used for Magic Player Rewards giveaways and the modern “Tips, Tricks, and Tokens” cards in boosters, built on Mark’s design by adding all the relevant game information that ties them to specific sets and cards--name, type, subtype, power, toughness, and rules text.

I didn’t buy much Unglued, but I got my hands on several of these Goblin tokens when I bought the Anthologies boxed set years ago. I suppose that product is the great-grandfather of the modern Duel Decks--it was two sixty-card decks balanced to play against one another, with some token cards added in as nice extra value. What’s old is new, etc.

Anthologies: http://www.wizards.com/magic/tcg/productarticle.aspx?x=mtg_tcg_anthologies_productinfo

5503: Goblin token card.author: sarroth
5503: Goblin token card.text_parsed:
@Aaron_Forsythe: Although I don't run any silver-bordered cards in normal decks, a couple, such as Mine, Mine, Mine and Ach! Hans, Run! work perfectly in my Chaos Magic set. For that reason alone I am glad for the sets' existence. In addition, some of the cards I just like having in my binder because they're so hilarious, such as Topsy Turvy.

As for the "proving ground," I very much like that. Thank you to The Cheese Stands Alone for Barren Glory, and thank you for tokens. I very much prefer it when players use tokens, as particularly in multiplayer a bunch of beads, flipped over cards from your graveyard, or Munchkin cards work fine when only one player has a token producer, but gets needlessly complicated with multiple different ones abounding. I know I've made a fair share of game mistakes because I misremembered what another player's token was. That's why I always have tokens handy.

As for this card specifically, not my favorite Goblin art.

5503: Goblin token card.author: ong312
5503: Goblin token card.text_parsed:
Some Un-tokens see play to this very day: Goblin, Soldier, Zombie... and others just get banished to the dust of history... Squirrel, Sheep...

Tokens are awesome, to be sure... If that were not the case, there would be no hunting for the super sexy New Phyrexia goblins or the elusive M12 6/6 Wurms... or the ever in demand 3/3 Lifelink and Deathtouch Wurms...

5503: Goblin token card.author: Cheza
5503: Goblin token card.text_parsed:
@ Aaron:

Although I like the idea of tokens, I don't like the numbers of token cards. What I really hate are cards that put copies of other complex card into play (see Mirrorworks).

Several years ago, there were no token cards at all, but we've decided to get vanilla creatures from the core set and give them the role of tokens. Goblin Scouts brings in 1/1 goblins with mountainwalk, so we used Goblin Mountaineer to represent these tokens. Likewise Mons's Goblin Raiders, Willow Elf and Scathe Zombies. The problem was that all these cards have a mana cost and are "real" cards. Some cards back then weren't able to handle non-cards aka. tokens (see Flicker).

I would appreciate a solution, where R&D finds a way to allow the vanilla creatures in the core set to represent tokens. Not only would this give those cards some value, it also decreases the need for tokens. My idea would be similar to "search for card you own from outside the game".

5712: Chaos Confetti.author: Orim-s_Thunder
5712: Chaos Confetti.text_parsed:
If they ever revisit this concept they ought to word it "Tear a Magic card you own into pieces...". This would allow you to rid yourself of cards you don't actually want while also giving you the same satisfaction.

Presumably because it's silver-bordered land, you can tear up your creature that your opponent stole from you in the process, or just some random card in your library or one in your hand. Interestingly though, a creature you tear up probably won't make it to the graveyard.

5712: Chaos Confetti.author: MyrBattlecube
5712: Chaos Confetti.text_parsed:
Here's a really long and complicated combo around this card that will probably result in lost friends.
What you need on the field:
Concordant Crossroads(or some enchantment that gives creatures haste, preferably in green)
Fastbond
Mindslaver
Feldon's Cane
A tapped Thran Weaponry
Karn, Silver Golem
Chaos Confetti
Rats of Rath
Mycosynth Lattice
Krosan Restorer enchanted with Freed from the Real
Staff of Domination
Teferi, Mage of Zhalfir
Simic Growth Chamber
And maybe some other lands. Doesn't really matter, though, thanks to Mycosynth Lattice. This goes a lot quicker if you've got threshold going.
What you need in your hand:
Sky Swallower
Mirrorweave

Okay so. You start by using Mindslaver to control their next turn. Pass to their turn. From your side, you make nine mana using the infinite mana combo available to your here(tap Simic Growth Chamber, tap Krosan Restorer to untap it, use Freed from the Real to untap Restorer), five of which will be used to flash in Sky Swallower, giving the opponent all permanents you control.

Now, back to the victim you're controlling. Generate a ton of mana using that combo. How much you need will depend on their deck, so just make a ton. Use Rats of Rath to kill off the Teferi. Now use Feldon's Cane to put their graveyard back into their library. Now, since you have infinite mana, use Staff of Domination to give the opponent a ton of life and to draw their entire deck. Use Fastbond to play all their lands and Mycosynth Lattice + infinite mana to play all their other permanents. Now, since they're all artifacts thanks to the Lattice, have Karn make the noncreatures into creatures. This is why you need that Thran Weaponry tapped, so their lands and other 0 cost things don't immediately go to the graveyard.

Back from your side, cast Mirrorweave on the Chaos Confetti so that all creatures(which should now be all permanents) are copies of Chaos Confetti. Proceed to rip all their permanents to shreds.

5712: Chaos Confetti.author: Kirbster

If your opponent is playing a Vesuvan Doppelganger (or some other shapeshifter,) and you have March of the Machines in play... you can steal the Doppelganger, have it copy the confetti, then tear it up on your opponent's cards.

Convoluted but terribly cruel.

5712: Chaos Confetti.author: Zetan
5712: Chaos Confetti.text_parsed: Someone already pointed out the use of Prototype Portal with Blacker Lotus, but it's even more useful with this. Even in the comp rules, the only mention of what a token can be represented by is "small items" (100.2). So if you use Prototype Portal, not only do you get to use the effect of Chaos Confetti without having to tear it up, but you can use any sort of "small item" as a token. Get creative! You could probably figure out something that you can tear up and be able to drop without as much flutter as a card.

5712: Chaos Confetti.author: rogelio
5712: Chaos Confetti.text_parsed: Instead of all these crazy combos of tearing up other people's cards and losing friends, you could just have this with R&D's Secret Lair out on the field. That way, when Chaos Confetti says "destroy each card in play that a piece touches", you can quite literally destroy the cards. You don't get the guarantee of your opponent losing all his/her cards, but it's short, simple, and to the point.

5712: Chaos Confetti.author: Jeremiahs-Mom
5712: Chaos Confetti.text_parsed:
Here's my Chaos Orb deck. I have a large stack of Chaos Confetti cards at all times because that's my favorite card in the deck. My son built this for me years ago so that I could hang out in card shops without dying of boredom LOL. It's been a long time since I updated it. Obviously a flipping deck, just for fun, but it's still my type of play because I'm not a serious player. I suggest building one for your mom, too!

Artifacts
x4 Chaos Orb, x4 Chaos Confetti, x4 Bottle of Suleiman, x4 Krark's Thumb

Creatures
x4 Mijae Djinn, x4 Wild Wurm, x4 Goblin Bookie, x2 Ydwen Efreet

Sorceries, Enchantments, Instants
x2 Fiery Gambit, x2 Falling Star, x4 Game of Chaos, x2 Mana Clash, x2 Chance Encounter, x2 Goblin Bomb, x2 Desperate Gambit

Here are the cards I'm thinking about adding:
Molten Birth
Orchish Paratroopers
Mana Flair
Dumb Ass
Volatile Rig
Puppet's Verdict
Gamble
Burning Cinder Fury of Crimson Chaos Fire (mostly because I love the name of this card!)

5725: Mesa Chicken.author: Buderus
5725: Mesa Chicken.text_parsed:
Wikipedia:

Domestic chickens are not capable of long distance flight, although lighter birds are generally capable of flying for short distances, such as over fences or into trees (where they would naturally roost). Chickens may occasionally fly briefly to explore their surroundings, but generally do so only to flee perceived danger.

________________________________

What Wikipedia forgot to write is that you only have to clap to make them fly... *clap*clap*
5725: Mesa Chicken.text_posted:
Wikipedia:

Domestic chickens are not capable of long distance flight, although lighter birds are generally capable of flying for short distances, such as over fences or into trees (where they would naturally roost). Chickens may occasionally fly briefly to explore their surroundings, but generally do so only to flee perceived danger.

________________________________

What Wikipedia forgot to write is that you only have to clap to make them fly... *clap*clap*

5824: Clam Session.author: tavaritz
5824: Clam Session.text_parsed:
Reminds me of an old (in nineteen nineties) conversation that happened between ministers of Finland and England:

EM: I've heard that there is no law in Finland that prohibits computer fraud. Is that true?
FM: Yes and no.
EM: What do you mean?
FM: In Finland we really don't have a law that prohibits computer fraud, but we do have a law that prohibits fraud.
EM: Why don't you pass a law that prohibits computer fraud?
FM: Because our fraud law doesn't speak anything about methods or tools or such. Fraud is a fraud and it doesn't matter how you commit it. It's still illegal in FInland.

Actually, if you cast it into the modern templating, the text would read "Put a red 4/4 Chicken token named 'Giant Chicken' into play". Of course, since they've committed to never updating the Oracle text on Un-cards, the people you're playing against may or may not realize that from the old templating.

9675: Free-Range Chicken.author: JimmyNoobPlayer
9675: Free-Range Chicken.text_parsed:
Megadog has a good point: you never sacrifice the Chicken if you roll a double. This means if you roll a double 1 or 6, you can roll again with zero risk.

The average value when rolling two dice is 7, and more extreme values are less likely. If you roll a 7, then you will sacrifice Free-Range Chicken on a reroll 1/6 of the time. If you roll a 3 or 11, you'll sacrifice on a reroll only 1/18 of the time.

If you roll an even number, the chance of sacrifice on a reroll is slightly less because doubles are possible. If you roll a 4 or 10, the chance of sacrifice on a reroll is 3/36 - 1/36 = 1/18.

already rolled an N this turn: chance of sacrifice from rolling another N
2: 1/36-1/36 = 0
3: 2/36 = 1/18
4: 3/36-1/36 = 1/18
5: 4/36 = 1/9
6: 5/36-1/36 = 1/9
7: 6/36 = 1/6
8: 1/9
9: 1/9
10: 1/18
11: 1/18
12: 0

For the first roll each turn, you'll get a double 1/6 of the time, and those doubles will be evenly distributed between the six numbers. On average, X will be 21/6/6 or 7/12. From a Spike perspective, it doesn't seem to compare favorably with Firebreathing!

9741: Charm School.author: Elysiume
9741: Charm School.text_parsed:
It's pretty obvious that the balancing is supposed to be sustained. If you got a call from the cops saying "close the door, there is a roving gang of murdering bandits," would you close your door, promptly open it, and giggle to yourself that you beat the system? If you pull that crap in actual games I pity anyone who plays against you. Finding loopholes in cards is just annoying.

As for the card, it's interesting. I'm not sure how easily I could balance a card on my head, but immunity is pretty nice.

9741: Charm School.author: nibelheim_valesti
9741: Charm School.text_parsed:
"You can just balance it to your head and then take it off your head."

Honestly... I really don't think you can. Putting the card on your head is mandated within the rules of the game, so I'd say you can't take it off unless a game effect tells you to.

That's like saying "Narcolepsy is useless, because after it taps my creature I'll just untap it again". You can't just choose to take gamestate-relevant actions unless a card or rule tells you to.

My two cents.
9741: Charm School.text_posted:
"You can just balance it to your head and then take it off your head."

Honestly... I really don't think you can. Putting the card on your head is mandated within the rules of the game, so I'd say you can't take it off unless a game effect tells you to.

That's like saying "[autocard]Narcolepsy [/autocard]is useless, because after it taps my creature I'll just untap it again". You can't just choose to take gamestate-relevant actions unless a card or rule tells you to.

My two cents.

9749: Chicken à la King.author: smilie23
9749: Chicken à la King.text_parsed:
to metalevolence:
I'm not a rules judge or anything but I'm pretty sure I know the answer to this one --
You can only tap a card that is untapped.
You can only untap a card that is tapped.
Confusion sometimes happens with some abilities that affect a card's tapped/untapped status, particularly Regeneration. Regenerate can be used on a tapped creature because it causes the card to BECOME tapped; tapping is not a COST of the regenerate, it is a side-effect.
So, the cost of the effect is 'Tap a chicken you control'; if you cannot pay the cost, you cannot roll the die.
9749: Chicken à la King.text_posted:
to  metalevolence:
I'm not a rules judge or anything but I'm pretty sure I know the answer to this one --
You can only tap a card that is untapped.
You can only untap a card that is tapped.
Confusion sometimes happens with some abilities that affect a card's tapped/untapped status, particularly Regeneration. Regenerate can be used on a tapped creature because it causes the card to BECOME tapped; tapping is not a COST of the regenerate, it is a side-effect. 
So, the cost of the effect is 'Tap a chicken you control'; if you cannot pay the cost, you cannot roll the die.

9749: Chicken à la King.author: NoobOfLore
9749: Chicken à la King.text_parsed:
It would have to be Errata'd to have the effect you are proposing, smilie.
You are legally permitted to tap permanents that are already tapped as part of an ability that is phrased that way, it would need to read "Tap an untapped chicken you control: roll a six-sided die." to play out the way you suggest.
There's a reason all the new cards that involve tapping things as a cost without the tap symbol specify an "untapped creature."
9749: Chicken à la King.text_posted:

There's a reason all the new cards that involve tapping things as a cost without the tap symbol specify an "untapped creature."

@phyrexiantrygon - That argument is irrelevant, Garruk's ruling involves a result, which will happen either way, whereas the question we're debating involves cost. If a cost can't be paid, the ability can't be used.

@NoobOfLore, stop living up to ur name :P It's a cost. If you can't pay the cost, you can't get the ability...and you can't tap something that happens to be tapped. If that was the case, everything that triggered when things tap, such as lust for warwould re-trigger if you use something like twiddle on it to tap it if it was already tapped. This doesn't work. Also, I would like to point out we are arguing on unglued cards...something that is only for fun. lol. If you disagree, play it differently around your table. Who cares.

9754: Spark Fiend.author: Chamale
9754: Spark Fiend.text_parsed:
The odds in craps are not in your favour, but this card has a chance of lasting long enough to be worthwhile.

89% chance that it reaches the field, with a 22% chance of winning instantly. After that, it has a 16% chance of dying during your upkeep, with an 11.5% chance of winning. With those odds, it should survive long enough for a red deck to burn the opponent to death.

If you actually want a good red 5-cost creature, though, I recommend Arc-Slogger, Kazuul, Tyrant of the Cliffs or Fire Servant.

Must Read: Best Combo Ever

There is a HILAROUS combo that I heard of involving a guy that used the Mycosynth Lattice / March of the Machines combo. What he did was Mindslaver his opponent, turn all cards in play into copies of Blacker Lotus using Mirrorweave and activate all of his permanents!

I don't remember who created that combo, but that man is the best Johnny ever.

Combo Broken Down For Those Confused:
1. Mycosynth Lattice makes all permanents artifacts.
2. March of the Machines turns all non-creature artifacts into creatures. (Blacker Lotus is an artifact creature now)
3. Mindslaver opponents turn.
4. During that turn, Mirrorweave targeting your Blacker Lotus creature.
5. ???
6. Profit!

@bijart_dauth: First of all artifact creatures abilities never stopped working when they were tapped.

Secondly the doesn't work tapped only applied to poly and continous artifacts, never to mono artifacts. When the separation was stopped and mono artifacts got the tap-symbol, the rule was mistakenly made that non-creature artifacts shut down when tapped. But then tapped Mana Vault won't ping you, said a rules lawyer. The rest you know: tapped artifacts work and some artifacts got errated to have words 'don't work when tapped', others didn't and some that did lost it later and no-one knows which alpha poly and continous artifacts work when tapped and which don't.

9769: Ashnod's Coupon.author: mutantman
9769: Ashnod's Coupon.text_parsed:
So, important ruling: Ashnod's Coupon does not combo with R&D's Secret Lair. If the player is unable to pay the drink's money cost, the coupon will have no effect. Ashnod's Coupon cannot force a player to activate money abilities to add money to his or her money pool; if the player chooses not to tap his or her wallet for money, he or she will not have to get the drink. This is the same interaction as Ghostly Prison + Alluring Siren.

For similar reasons, you cannot force a player to get you a drink in a foreign country. Also, you cannot force a minor to buy you alcohol; if you attempt this, the ability will be countered upon resolution because its targets are illegal.
9769: Ashnod's Coupon.text_posted:

This is the same interaction as [autocard]Ghostly Prison[/autocard] + [autocard]Alluring Siren[/autocard].

For similar reasons, you cannot force a player to get you a drink in a foreign country. Also, you cannot force a minor to buy you alcohol; if you attempt this, the ability will be countered upon resolution because its targets are illegal.

9769: Ashnod's Coupon.author: Totema
9769: Ashnod's Coupon.text_parsed:
I read that there's a way to turn this into a win condition. I think how that could work is like so:
1. Get it onto the field. Make sure there is a drink you actually own nearby.
2. Donate it to your opponent.
3. Mindslaver, and during your opponent's turn, tap this. Target your opponent and make him fetch you your own drink.
4. Since it's your drink, you can choose your own price for it. Say something such as "all the money in your wallet" to avoid tricky rulings regarding being able to afford it.
Either they pay up, or they can concede. Nasty.

9770: Urza's Contact Lenses.author: Tanaka348
9770: Urza's Contact Lenses.text_parsed:
Heheheh.... you can't go off with this card unless you can pay the cost enough times! How long can your hands hold out?

By the way, for those confused about the random tap on tap off, back in the day when Unglued was printed and it was still pre-6th edition, artifacts used to not work as a rule while they were tapped. I'd honestly go ahead and say for the sake of original intent and more importantly, fun, you should treat this card as having some sort of Howling Mine-esque errata so it works as intended again. It's not much worse than making those Unglued interrupts instants.

9771: Look at Me, I'm the DCI.author: adrian.malacoda
9771: Look at Me, I'm the DCI.text_parsed:
Not strictly worse than Nevermore. Nevermore does not affect lands, it doesn't stop the card from being cheated onto the battlefield, and its effect ends as soon as it is removed or when the game is over. This effect is more like Cranial Extraction that lasts the entire match (and hits all players, which is relevant in multiplayer).

I could easily see a black bordered variant of this, maybe in Orzhov colors or mono-black, at 5 or 6 CMC. Obviously it wouldn't last for the remainder of the match.

9772: Once More with Feeling.author: bduddy
9772: Once More with Feeling.text_parsed:
It can't actually restrict itself.

112.6m. An ability that modifies the rules for deck construction functions before the game begins. Such an ability modifies not just the Comprehensive Rules, but also the Magic: The Gathering Tournament Rules and any other documents that set the deck construction rules for a specific Constructed format. However, such an ability can't affect the format legality of a card, including whether it's banned or restricted. The current Magic: The Gathering Tournament Rules can be found at Wizards.com/WPN/Events/Rules.aspx.

9773: The Cheese Stands Alone.author: Alpha-Black
9773: The Cheese Stands Alone.text_parsed: Capable of Instant Win combo with Oblivion Ring and Apocalypse.  It is possible to get the instant win on turn 4.  Don't believe me?  I'll explain.  1) Play Forest, cast Llanowar Elves.  2) Play Plains, use both lands and Llanowar Elves to cast Nantuko Elder.  3) Play a second Plains, tap everything to cast The Cheese Stands Alone.  4) Play Mountain.  Tap Forest, Plains, and Elves to cast Oblivion Ring targeting The Cheese.  Tap Mountain and Elder to cast Seething Song.  Use Song mana to cast Apocalypse.  You win.

9773: The Cheese Stands Alone.author: syrazemyla
9773: The Cheese Stands Alone.text_parsed:
Okay, scrubs, here's how to win with The Cheese Stands Alone.

Get it out, along with Time Machine, Liquimetal Coating, and March of the Machines. Your Time Machine is now a creature. Use Liquimetal Coating on The Cheese Stands Alone so it becomes an artifact creature. Now use Cytoshape or Mirrorweave to turn it into a copy of Time Machine. Cast Accursed Centaur, and then exile it with The Cheese Stands Alone's Time Machine ability.

Next game, mulligan to 0 cards. At the start of the first turn, Accursed Centaur and The Cheese Stands Alone come into play. The centaur sacrifices itself, and you win instantly.

Winning the game where you set up the combo is an exercise for the reader.

9773: The Cheese Stands Alone.author: SnackyNorph
9773: The Cheese Stands Alone.text_parsed:
Convoluted win-con of the week! I don't play Magic in Happy Fairy Dreamland, so this is going to be an "if your battlefield has this" post rather than a "you shoot magic pixie dust out of your nose and draw everything you ever need" post.
Step 1) Leyline of Anticipation on the battlefield.
Step 2) Somehow have the mana for both Worldfire and The Cheese Stands Alone.
Step 3) Simple matter of playing The Cheese Stands Alone, then flashing Worldfire on the stack.
Step 3b) Worldfire resolves, utterly destroying the field and card advantage and all of those fun shenanigans. Then, good ol' The Cheese Stands Alone resolves, enters the battlefield, and immediately wins you the game.

9774: I'm Rubber, You're Glue.author: Lyoncet
9774: I'm Rubber, You're Glue.text_parsed:
Of course, it doesn't say that you have to speak in any particular meter, just that the words have to rhyme. It doesn't even say that the sentences have to make sense; as long as you get the idea across and it ends with a word that rhymes with another word in the sentence, it would be legit with how the card's printed. I'm dead serious.

For example, I could rewrite the prior paragraph like this: "It doesn't say I have to speak in meter; it just needs rhyming words water heater. And as long as you know the effect I desire, the words don't even really have to make all that much sense car tire. That's what the rules say, don't look at me; I blame those lazy bums at R&D."

And it does have great synergy with Atinlay Igpay, since in Pig Latin, almost everything rhymes anyways (if you can speak it, that is).

9776: Sorry.author: Gelzo
9776: Sorry.text_parsed:
Player 1: "Sure is fun playing with these Un- cards. I'm seeing all sorts of interesting cards I've never seen before."

Player 2: "Yep. So, I'm casting this card. Let it resolve?"

Player 1: "Yeah, don't have any counters. What does it do?"

Player 2: "Why don't you go ahead and read it aloud so we can get everyone else here acquainted with it?"

Player 1: "Sure thing. Let's see... 'Sorry': 'Before playing any spell, if a copy of that spell card is in any graveyard, the spell's caster may say 'Sorry.' If he or she does not, any other player may counter the spell by saying 'Sorry' as it is cast.

If any player says 'Sorry' at any other time, Sorry deals 2 damage to that pla-' Oh my."

Player 2: "So, 10 damage then?"

Player 1: "..."

Player 2: "I apologize."

9777: Psychic Network.author: VDZx
9777: Psychic Network.text_parsed:
@littlebeast
Actually, you're allowed to look at the card with YAAV. Psychic Network just reveals the card to opponents, while not modifying rules about you viewing your library - you can't see it because you can't see your top card without a card specifically stating you can do so. YAAV, however, says both that the top card is revealed (to all players, including you) and that the top card is in play (which allows you to view it).

However, Psychic Network's forehead restriction still counts. You'll have to ask your opponents about what card you're holding up or use a mirror, but the rules state you are allowed to know.

9778: Bureaucracy.author: Yukikah
9778: Bureaucracy.text_parsed:
@Dwarf Planet; I don't know why people have trouble with this card. Easy enough to translate:

There player A, and his opponent player B. Player A played this enchantment. During player B's next upkeep, they do action W, which is an action that is a simple physical or verbal action that has no risk of physical or mental harm and can be performed while sitting down. Let's say for action W player B decides to snap his fingers on both hands at once.

During player A's next upkeep they must perform action W (snapping their fingers) then add another action to this queue of actions that is being built up, referring to this new action as action X. Let's say action X is saying a tongue twister. In other words, when it comes to player A's upkeep here, they have to snap their fingers then they say the tongue twister.

This continues on, with each player adding to the action queue with each of their upkeeps. So during player B's next upkeep, they have to snap their fingers and say the tongue twister then add yet another action. The players keep adding actions during their upkeep after doing all the previous actions in order. When one of the players is unable to do all the previous actions in the queue during their upkeep, in order, the effect of the card kicks in and that player has to discard all the cards in their hand.

Maybe it's a long explanation, but if you just grasp the simple understanding of what it's asking you to do, the wording becomes irrelevant.
9778: Bureaucracy.text_posted:
@Dwarf Planet;  I don't know why people have trouble with this card.  Easy enough to translate:

There player A, and his opponent player B.  Player A played this enchantment.  During player B's next upkeep, they do action W, which is an action that is a simple physical or verbal action that has no risk of physical or mental harm and can be performed while sitting down.  Let's say for action W player B decides to snap his fingers on both hands at once.

During player A's next upkeep they must perform action W (snapping their fingers) then add another action to this queue of actions that is being built up, referring to this new action as action X.  Let's say action X is saying a tongue twister.  In other words, when it comes to player A's upkeep here, they have to snap their fingers then they say the tongue twister.

This continues on, with each player adding to the action queue with each of their upkeeps.  So during player B's next upkeep, they have to snap their fingers and say the tongue twister then add yet another action.  The players keep adding actions during their upkeep after doing all the previous actions in order.  When one of the players is unable to do all the previous actions in the queue during their upkeep, in order, the effect of the card kicks in and that player has to discard all the cards in their hand.

Maybe it's a long explanation, but if you just grasp the simple understanding of what it's asking you to do, the wording becomes irrelevant.

9778: Bureaucracy.author: Salient
9778: Bureaucracy.text_parsed:
Is this the dragon's maze of DRAGON'S MAZE? Time will tell...

For confused folks: The card requires you and your opponent to play a game like Simon (that game with four light-up buttons that beep longer and longer patterns for you to remember and enter). At the beginning of each player's upkeep, they repeat all the motions the person before them did, then add another motion. A motion can be either a gesture or spoken phrase.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_(game)

The biggest problem with this card (both conceptually and practically) is that your opponent is the first person to make a motion. If they're clever enough to start things off with something really complicated, it can easily be for "At the beginning of your next upkeep, discard your hand." The card's only awesome in multiplayer, where you have four or five opponents that could screw it up before you do.

But even then, an opponent will eventually figure out that they can say, "If my name is , then I hereby forfeit this game. Even if this is spoken as part of the upkeep trigger for Bureaucracy, my forfeiture stands."

9778: Bureaucracy.author: CamperCarl00
9778: Bureaucracy.text_parsed:
@ Salient:

"All actions must be simple physical or verbal actions that a player can perform while sitting in a chair, without jeopardizing the health and security of said PLAYER."

You can easily say that if an opponent declares "If my name is , then I hereby forfeit this game. Even if this is spoken as part of the upkeep trigger for Bureaucracy, my forfeiture stands." that it's a jeopardizing of the security of the initial player and that it's far from a simple verbal action. In addition, if the opponent is hasty and proceeds to draw their card before you can make your rebuttal, then you can then say they failed to add an action and must therefore discard their hand before drawing for the turn.

9780: B.F.M. (Big Furry Monster).author: ErnieZer0
9780: B.F.M. (Big Furry Monster).text_parsed:
This creature is so awesome, really want to get him. but why people complain about one side being good and the other not, I think the point of a "two card for one creature" thing is, that if it were just one card, then it'll be stupidly powerful and everyone with a black deck will get one, hell, people without black will put it in their decks just to have it. also, if you gave it trample or reach or something like that, again, it would be too powerful. Plus anything that blocks it, except darksteel and regenerating creatures, will die, and your opponent has to do that with 3 creatures.
Eldrazi based decks won't be able to stop this thing. He attacks you, what a shame, you sacrifice other cards, you attack him, either he blocks and loses 3 of his precious eldrazi, or he dies. SIMPLE AS!

Basically, if you want to really kick ass with it, equip darksteel plate and whispersilk cloak, then your opponent will never be able to get rid of it. *Evil Planning*

9780: B.F.M. (Big Furry Monster).author: infinight
9780: B.F.M. (Big Furry Monster).text_parsed:
This is NOT the scariest creature I have ever seen. That title goes to Emrakul, who has haste (via extra turn), Flying, proxies himself (via extra turn), untaps all lands you control (via extra turn), is uncounterable and can be killed by almost nothing. The fact that one hit from him makes you sacrifice 6 permanents really never makes a difference in the game since that's usually enought to finish you.

This guy dies to every type of removal, is nearly impossible to play, requires a second cost to get out, and can still be chump-blocked by anything with deathtouch. The fact that he costs 15 of one color means that there's a very small chance of ever giving him useful abilities like trample and haste too.

9780: B.F.M. (Big Furry Monster).author: Mode
9780: B.F.M. (Big Furry Monster).text_parsed:
I always imagined the face of the guy that pulled either side of this card in his packs.

"Creature type: The Biggest, Baddest, Nastiest, Scariest Creature You Ever Did See
I wonder if this is a valid creature type.. XD"

@BastianQoU It was in fact, for even quite a long time, listed in the Comprehensive Rules Book - until the Grand Creature Type update.
Before that, for some hilarious reason, it was legit to choose from any of those potentially ridiculous creature types available in any of the Un-Sets.
(Although admittedly, i'm not 100% sure about that, i've once heard that that it was never truly possibly because Silver-bordered cards obviously aren't part of official Expansions, and similar quirks from Un-sets (like choosing pink or hazel as a color) aren't legal either. But as i said, they were listed in the official rules book, at least. Even then, it didn't matter that much, since there were still plenty of weird creatures to choose from, like Ali-from-Cairo, Devouring-Deep, El-Hajjâj or People-of-the-Woods. Dandân was one of my personal favorite choices.)

BFM's type was unmissable in the old lists that included all of the creature types available in Magic.
It would have been written with Hyphens as The-Biggest-Baddest-Nastiest-Scariest-Creature-You'll-Ever-See.

So yes, at some point in the game, during a Conspiracy, all of your creatures could turn into
The-Biggest-Baddest-Nastiest-Scariest-Creature-You'll-Ever-Sees (that's the plural term).
Your Imagecrafter was even capable of turning Phage into a Lady-of-Proper-Etiquette.
Even after stepping out of the silver-bordered realm, you could make Volrath your brother with a Trickery Charm.

9780: B.F.M. (Big Furry Monster).author: DeaTh-ShiNoBi
9780: B.F.M. (Big Furry Monster).text_parsed:
@HSDclover
It is a shame that you are "technically" not correct. Eldrazi do not have genders. You're thinking of the Kor and Merfolk sky goddesses. Both the Kor and Merfolk used long forgotten memories of Emrakul as inspiration for their sky goddess, Kamsa and Emeria, respectively. Both races assigned a female gender to their sky deity, but the real Emrakul has no gender.
9780: B.F.M. (Big Furry Monster).text_posted:
@HSDclover
It is a shame that you are "technically" not correct.  Eldrazi do not have genders.  You're thinking of the Kor and Merfolk sky goddesses.  Both the Kor and Merfolk used long forgotten memories of Emrakul as inspiration for their sky goddess, Kamsa and Emeria, respectively.  Both races assigned a female gender to their sky deity, but the real Emrakul has no gender.

9782: Jalum Grifter.text_parsed:
Since you have to keep the cards on the table, you can't actually do the 'three card monte' shown in the illustration. In that scam, if the dealer picks up two of the three cards, he can imperceptibly throw either the top or the bottom one onto the table, and make it appear as if the bottom one has been thrown in order to deceive the person who is betting on the game.

Oh right, the card. Most of the time (barring shenanigans, like above) your opponent will be able to follow which one is where. You can sometimes get lucky, and you can activate it in response to removal, but most of the time it will just be a 3/5. The fun that you get out of his ability is gravy.

9783: Burning Cinder Fury of Crimson Cha.author: Tanaka348
9783: Burning Cinder Fury of Crimson Cha.text_parsed:
You know, you'd think this wouldn't be hard card to implement in "real" magic. But it turns out modern templating causes quite a mess here with ability #1. First of all, you don't specify players tapping cards anymore, unless you specifically are going to have them "tap a land for mana". This card actually illustrates why this is a case... what happens when you use an Icy Manipulator on an opponent's card? Do they give it to one of their opponents? Do you give it to one of your opponents, since you're the one that tapped it? Does nothing happen because it's not yours to give?

Second is that nowadays all control effects are "foo gains control of blah". Now, what's the huge problem here? All this reordering totally kills the antecedents... you start with foo, which is... an opponent of controller of the card, but on top of that, it's the choice of the controller of the card which of his opponents it is! The problem is because the controller of Burning Long Name is always the "you" whenever text says you, you have fits trying to refer to a choice made by an arbitrary person that is restricted to that person's opponents.

In my best guess, and keeping in mind we're making a new "real" magic card so we don't have to have it work exactly the same... "Whenever a permanent becomes tapped, its controller chooses one of his or her opponents. That opponent gains control of that permanent at the beginning of the next end step."

Wow, that didn't actually turn out that bad. I guess for completion's sake, the second ability would be "At the beginning of each player's end step, CARDNAME deals 3 damage to that player unless a nonland permanent they control became tapped this turn."

Everytime. Everytime I play this, I begin to do... this. Do note that this is an actual conversation I've had during a game:

'WELCOME! IT'S TIME TO PLAY STRATEGY, SCHMATEGY!"
"what are you talki-"
"OUR NEXT CONTESTANT: A 16-YEAR OLD MALE NAMED (friends name), ATTENDING HIGH SCHOOL, WHO LOVES TO NAP!"
"stop."
"NOW PLEASE, MY FRIEND, SPIN THE WHEEL OF FORTUNE AND GEEEEEEET READY TO ROLL!"
(Rolls dice)
"OH, AND THE FUN HAS JUST STARTED: YOU ROLLED A 6! THAT MEANS THAT YOU GET TO ROLL ANOTHER TWO TIMES!"
"'sigh'"
(rolls)
"ANNNND WE'VE GOT A 3... AND A 1... (makes sad flute sound) TOO BAD, BUT THE FUN DOESN'T STOP JUST YET! READ... OUT... YOUR... PRIZE!"
"Destroy all l- Go eat a D*ck"
"THANKS FOR PLAYING! IT'S NOW TIME TO DROP DA HAMMER! (making exploding sounds while throwing my lands into the grave). THANKS FOR PLAYING!"
"I don't like playing with you."
"And I don't like it when you play Elvish Piper so you can play a second-turn Blightsteel Colossus, but, you know... you have to have a little give and take"

And that's a standard magic game with my friends.

9787: Mine, Mine, Mine!.author: Feathermind
9787: Mine, Mine, Mine!.text_parsed:
Disenchant it in response to the comes into play trigger. (Actual Disenchant won't work due to the one spell/turn clause, but Seal of Cleansing will, or Seal of Primordium for the in-color equivalent.) The leaves play trigger goes off first, and every player shuffles their entire graveyard and hand into their library. then the comes into play trigger goes off and they take that entire library into their hand, but without the security of the now absent draw clauses. Then play passes around the table, and unless any player has a single instant answer playable anywhere in their library, than each opponent loses on their draw phase.
Fair warning, it's amusing exactly once, and may very well destroy what joy people get out of this card from simply having full access to their library. Unglued cards are meant for fun, so make sure not to lose sight of that when toying with a card as brimming with potential as this beauty.

Then play passes around the table, and unless any player has a single instant answer playable anywhere in their library, than each opponent loses on their draw phase.
Fair warning, it's amusing exactly once, and may very well destroy what joy people get out of this card from simply having full access to their library.  Unglued cards are meant for fun, so make sure not to lose sight of that when toying with a card as brimming with potential as this beauty.

9844: B.F.M. (Big Furry Monster, Right S.author: DarthParallax
9844: B.F.M. (Big Furry Monster, Right S.text_parsed:
B.F.M. stands for Big. ***. MONSTER. o.o

This doesn't need any combat trick that they probably already printed a card or cards for that gives the desired ability. They design things like that for the EXPRESS purpose of giving to guys like this. BUT- it does need one line that I wish they'd thought about:

"B.F.M. can block any number of creatures whose total power does not exceed its toughness."

So, really really really giant hordes of demonic elf tokens or saproling tokens or whatever will still get through, but most usual armies should be blockable by this guy. And then leave it up to the player to find out how to give it vigilance.
9844: B.F.M. (Big Furry Monster, Right S.text_posted:
B.F.M. stands for Big. Fucking. MONSTER. o.o

This doesn't need any combat trick that they probably already printed a card or cards for that gives the desired ability. They design things like that for the EXPRESS purpose of giving to guys like this. BUT- it does need one line that I wish they'd thought about: 

"B.F.M. can block any number of creatures whose total power does not exceed its toughness."

So, really really really giant hordes of demonic elf tokens or saproling tokens or whatever will still get through, but most usual armies should be blockable by this guy. And then leave it up to the player to find out how to give it vigilance.

9844: B.F.M. (Big Furry Monster, Right S.author: Guest392185251
9844: B.F.M. (Big Furry Monster, Right S.text_parsed:
"Some call her the BFM. I call her my BFF.
That summer we grew closer and closer as we shared many a bowl of Thallid covered in the low-fat tears of our enemies.
But our adventure together began the night I implemented my intricate plot to steal from my demon master at the Hot Topic. As I stood in the parking lot revealing my ill-gotten loot: a Grumpy Cat belly tee, I saw the corners of her lips begin to turn upwards.
"Don't laugh," I squealed in protest, "Thalia picked it for me."
"How predictable." chuckled my BFF. But her chuckle soon turned to an uproar that shattered the Hel-mall. With that, our interests lie elsewhere..."

- Liliana Vess
Sisterhood of the Travelling Veil

They wouldn't want to.
